titleStmt.title: Josephus, The Jewish War 1.613-1.616
Caesarea Maritima: A Collection of Testimonia

publicationStmt.authority: Caesarea City and Port Exploration Project

licence.p: Distributed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 Unported License.

editorialDecl.p: Authors of testimonia are identified with URIs from The Virtual International Authority File, seehttp://viaf.org. When multiple VIAF URIs exist, preference has been given to VIAF record linked to the Library of Congress authority file.
Geographic locations are identified with URIs from Pleiades: A Gazetteer of Past Places, seehttps://pleiades.stoa.org/docs.

When possible, textual works have been cited using URNs according to the Distributed Text Services (DTS) system, seehttps://distributed-text-services.github.io/specifications). Additional identifiers have been adopted from the systems used by the Perseus Digital Library (http://www.perseus.tufts.edu), Syriaca.org (http://syriaca.org), and other relevant authority systems such as WorldCat Identities or OCLC numbers (https://www.worldcat.org).
Bibliographic items are identified by a caesarea-maritima.org URI, which is linked, when possible to OCLC numbers and other identifiers.
Dates have been encoded following the ISO 8601 standard,https://www.iso.org/iso-8601-date-and-time-format.html, and the best practices established by for the Sroph√© App, seehttp://srophe.app.
Languages have been encoded using ISO 639-1, 639-2, and 639-3 codes, following best practices of the TEI guidelines.

taxonomy.desc:
Caesarea-Maritima.org Chronology: This chronology is adapted from the chronology used in The New Encyclopedia of Archaeological Excavations in the Holy Land
Ephraim Stern
Ayelet Levinzon-Gilbo'a
J. Aviram
. This taxonomy is used in thecatRefencoding to classify the testimonia according to the time period(s) of the events described, rather than the date of composition of the testimonium. For example, Josephus may describe events occuring well before the period of his writing.
Caesarea-Maritima.org Testimonia Typology: This typology defines three subsets of testimonia employed by the project and is used in the catRef below to further categorize a given testimonia record.

category.catDesc: A "direct testimonium" contains a word or phrase that is a direct reference to, or name for, the conceptual place Caeseara Maritima or its environs in part or in whole. When a "direct testimonium" also contains indirect references, the classification by type is nevertheless marked only as "direct".

An "indirect testimonium" makes only an indirect reference to the conceptual place Caeseara Maritima or its environs in part or in whole. This indirect reference may take the form of a common noun or may be implied by context.

A "toponymic testimonium" contains a toponymic epithet related to the conceptual place Caeseara Maritima or its environs. When a "direct testimonium" also contain a "toponymic testimonium", the testimonium is marked as belonging to both types. These two types do not always overlap and thus our data set also includes "toponymic testimonia" which are not "direct testimonia".

profileDesc.creation: This entry is taken from The Jewish War 1.613-1.616 written by Josephus in 70 - 90 CE. This work was likely written in Rome.

revisionDesc.change: CHANGED: Update bibl elements with full citation information from Syriaca.org entry.
ADDED: testimonium ID, URNs, URLs to edition and translation, and Bibl URIs

urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0526.tlg004.perseus-grc1:1.613-1.616

Antipater complied with this last advice, for Providence hurried him on [to his destruction]. So he passed over the sea, and landed at Sebastus, the haven of Cesarea. And here he found a perfect and unexpected solitude, while ever body avoided him, and nobody durst come at him; for he was equally hated by all men; and now that hatred had liberty to show itself, and the dread men were in at the king's anger made men keep from him; for the whole city [of Jerusalem] was filled with the rumors about Antipater, and Antipater himself was the only person who was ignorant of them; for as no man was dismissed more magnificently when he began his voyage to Rome so was no man now received back with greater ignominy. And indeed he began already to suspect what misfortunes there were in Herod's family; yet did he cunningly conceal his suspicion; and while he was inwardly ready to die for fear, he put on a forced boldness of countenance. Nor could he now fly any whither, nor had he any way of emerging out of the difficulties which encompassed him; nor indeed had he even there any certain intelligence of the affairs of the royal family, by reason of the threats the king had given out: yet had he some small hopes of better tidings; for perhaps nothing had been discovered; or if any discovery had been made, perhaps he should be able to clear himself by impudence and artful tricks, which were the only things he relied upon for his deliverance.
urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0526.tlg004.perseus-eng1:1.608-1.614

bibl.title: De Bello Judaico Libri VII: Machine Readable Text
The Wars of the Jews: Machine Readable Text
